bibl.title: Letter from J.O. Gawne to William Houston Lazear, April 13, 1926

div1.p: Gawne offers to send copies of letters to William Lazear that pay tribute to his father.

div1.head: Letter from J.O. Gawne to William Houston Lazear, April 13, 1926

opener.dateline:
BUREAU OF CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR,
NAVY DEPARTMENT,
WASHINGTON, D. C.
13 April 1926.

div1.p:
Mrs. Gawne and I were going over some old letters
the other night, preparatory to our next change of duty,
which occurs in July, and came across two old letters
written by Mr. T. C. Lazear, your great uncle and Mrs.
Gawne's grandfather. I quote the following from his
letter of May 31, 1914, in acknowledgement of the “Life
of Admiral Dewey” sent him as a birthday present:

“Jane's kind letter of congratulation and the
autobiography of Admiral Dewey sent by Jim, which
I understand is a gift from you both in honor of
that day, gave me inexpressible pleasure and I thank
you most heartily for these tokens of remembrance.
I have been asking myself the question and wondering
whether I should not write also to Admiral Dewey to
thank him for the handsome tribute to the memory of
my nephew, Dr. Jesse W. Lazear, which appears on the
fly-leaf of that book in the Admiral's own hand-
writing. Valuable and interesting as the book is
to others, this particular volume is immensely precious
to Dr. Jesse W. Lazear's family and relatives by
reason of that tribute coming from one so eminent
and famous. ------------ I propose when Dr. Jesse's
only son, Houston, arrives at the proper age to
deliver the book into his custody, to be kept for-
ever in the family as a precious heirloom. Houston
is only fifteen years of age but an exceptionally
bright promising boy”.

When Mr. Lazear died a few years ago this book was
sent back to us and at the time we had forgotten the con-
tents of his letter and, therefore, had never thought of
sending it to you. In view of the wish which Mr. Lazear
expressed, it would give me great pleasure to send the
book to you and thus carry out the wish which he expressed.
If you will confirm your address, I will be very glad to
send it on at once.

I am sorry that distances are so great that
we see practically nothing of you and your
family, and as we rather expect to go to London
this summer for duty, it will probably be a
couple of years before we can count on seeing
each other.
With kindest regards to you and yours,
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours J.O. Gawne Mr. Houston Lazear,
#60 Oakvale Street,
Berkeley, California.
